content: So, someone explain to me again exactly how Obama is going to cut the deficit in half, and pay for his liberal spending bonanza for all of his social programs? How high will he have to raise taxes on those who still have jobs? We already have too many dollars chasing too few goods, which is going to result in massive inflation, and less spending, which means even less tax revenue for the Federal coffers. quote: Federal tax revenue plunged $138 billion, or 34%, in April vs. a year ago — the biggest April drop since 1981, a study released Tuesday by the American Institute for Economic Research says. When the economy slumps, so does tax revenue, and this recession has been no different, says Kerry Lynch, senior fellow at the AIER and author of the study. "It illustrates how severe the recession has been." For example, 6 million people lost jobs in the 12 months ended in April — and that means far fewer dollars from income taxes. Income tax revenue dropped 44% from a year ago. "These are staggering numbers," Lynch says. Big revenue losses mean that the U.S. budget deficit may be larger than predicted this year and in future years. Source: "http://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/taxes/2009-05-26-irs-tax-revenue-down_N.htm" "The World's Finest"
quote: Federal tax revenue plunged $138 billion, or 34%, in April vs. a year ago — the biggest April drop since 1981, a study released Tuesday by the American Institute for Economic Research says. "It illustrates how severe the recession has been." For example, 6 million people lost jobs in the 12 months ended in April — and that means far fewer dollars from income taxes. Income tax revenue dropped 44% from a year ago. "These are staggering numbers," Lynch says. Big revenue losses mean that the U.S. budget deficit may be larger than predicted this year and in future years. Source: "http://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/taxes/2009-05-26-irs-tax-revenue-down_N.htm"

How high will he have to raise taxes on those who still have jobs? We already have too many dollars chasing too few goods, which is going to result in massive inflation, and less spending, which means even less tax revenue for the Federal coffers.  "The World's Finest"

content: quote: Well the vat tax is coming.... thats the solution for a lib. no VAT is not coming. They already said it's not going to happen. as for the Federal Tax Revenue drop.....see...we're in what you call a recession...thats what happens during a recession. and thats why you have deficet during a recession. because you need the increased spending to bring you out of the recession and the tax Revenue is down. what gb2 did is drain a surplus and run the government in the red when we weren't in a recession. just like gb1 and Saint Ronnie did. Thats why we're 10 trillion in debt instead of just 1 or 2 trillion. and THAT'S why no one believes it when the republicans talk about smaller government and fiscal conserativism. I understand that Obama is a "D" and you guys aren't but do at least TRY to put things into perspective.

content: quote: Originally posted by ELLIOTT1980: O K . . ., BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! Now that I have the LIBs attention . . ., how does two wrongs, PO growing the Federal Government ever larger than BUSH 43..., gonna fix the problem . . . I'm getting this 'Deja Vu' of two wrongs, dang sure, don't make a right . . ., please explain It is not a matter of two wrongs making a right – it is a matter of what’s the difference? Republicans who call the kettle black when it got burned up on their watch have no credibility – that is why referring to what happened when Republicans controlled Congress and the White House matters. Under President Bush’s supervision, the national dept grew from $5.706 trillion in 2000 to $8.507 trillion in October 2007. That is DURING THE TIME THAT THE REPUBLICANS CONTROLLED CONGRESS – without one veto from President Bush. Note for those who will make excuses for President Bush: the GWOT represented only half a trillion dollars of the almost three trillion dollars that was overspent from January 2000 until October 2007, when the last Republican budget ended. From an article published in June 2004 – it got worse after this revelation, before the Republicans lost control of Congress: "Since 2001, even with record low inflation, U.S. federal spending has increased by a massive 28.8% (19.7% in real dollars)—with non-defense discretionary growth of 35.7% (25.3% in real dollars)—the highest rate of federal government growth since the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Lyndon Johnson.. President George W. Bush is now on his way to becoming the first full-term president since John Quincy Adams (1825-1829) to not veto a single bill. The result is a congress that has been completely unconstrained in satiating its appetite for pork and corporate welfare. From the massive increases in agricultural subsidies in the farm bill of 2002, to the new Medicare prescription drug entitlement of 2003, to the 80% increase in education spending, George W. Bush has demonstrated that “limited government” is not part of his political vocabulary." >www.independent.org/newsroom/news_detail.asp?newsID=31]http://www.independent.org/new...detail.asp?newsID=31 I am against the spending by the Obama Administration also, but what is the alternative – the good old days of a Republican controlled government?
quote: Originally posted by ELLIOTT1980: O K . . ., BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! Now that I have the LIBs attention . . ., how does two wrongs, PO growing the Federal Government ever larger than BUSH 43..., gonna fix the problem . . . I'm getting this 'Deja Vu' of two wrongs, dang sure, don't make a right . . ., please explain
reply: It is not a matter of two wrongs making a right – it is a matter of what’s the difference? Republicans who call the kettle black when it got burned up on their watch have no credibility – that is why referring to what happened when Republicans controlled Congress and the White House matters. Under President Bush’s supervision, the national dept grew from $5.706 trillion in 2000 to $8.507 trillion in October 2007. That is DURING THE TIME THAT THE REPUBLICANS CONTROLLED CONGRESS – without one veto from President Bush. Note for those who will make excuses for President Bush: the GWOT represented only half a trillion dollars of the almost three trillion dollars that was overspent from January 2000 until October 2007, when the last Republican budget ended. From an article published in June 2004 – it got worse after this revelation, before the Republicans lost control of Congress: "Since 2001, even with record low inflation, U.S. federal spending has increased by a massive 28.8% (19.7% in real dollars)—with non-defense discretionary growth of 35.7% (25.3% in real dollars)—the highest rate of federal government growth since the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Lyndon Johnson.. President George W. Bush is now on his way to becoming the first full-term president since John Quincy Adams (1825-1829) to not veto a single bill. The result is a congress that has been completely unconstrained in satiating its appetite for pork and corporate welfare. From the massive increases in agricultural subsidies in the farm bill of 2002, to the new Medicare prescription drug entitlement of 2003, to the 80% increase in education spending, George W. Bush has demonstrated that “limited government” is not part of his political vocabulary." >www.independent.org/newsroom/news_detail.asp?newsID=31]http://www.independent.org/new...detail.asp?newsID=31 I am against the spending by the Obama Administration also, but what is the alternative – the good old days of a Republican controlled government?

content: So, someone explain to me again exactly how Obama is going to cut the deficit in half, and pay for his liberal spending bonanza for all of his social programs? How high will he have to raise taxes on those who still have jobs? We already have too many dollars chasing too few goods, which is going to result in massive inflation, and less spending, which means even less tax revenue for the Federal coffers. quote: Federal tax revenue plunged $138 billion, or 34%, in April vs. a year ago — the biggest April drop since 1981, a study released Tuesday by the American Institute for Economic Research says. When the economy slumps, so does tax revenue, and this recession has been no different, says Kerry Lynch, senior fellow at the AIER and author of the study. "It illustrates how severe the recession has been." For example, 6 million people lost jobs in the 12 months ended in April — and that means far fewer dollars from income taxes. Income tax revenue dropped 44% from a year ago. "These are staggering numbers," Lynch says. Big revenue losses mean that the U.S. budget deficit may be larger than predicted this year and in future years. Source: "http://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/taxes/2009-05-26-irs-tax-revenue-down_N.htm" "The World's Finest"
quote: Federal tax revenue plunged $138 billion, or 34%, in April vs. a year ago — the biggest April drop since 1981, a study released Tuesday by the American Institute for Economic Research says. When the economy slumps, so does tax revenue, and this recession has been no different, says Kerry Lynch, senior fellow at the AIER and author of the study. "It illustrates how severe the recession has been." For example, 6 million people lost jobs in the 12 months ended in April — and that means far fewer dollars from income taxes. Income tax revenue dropped 44% from a year ago. "These are staggering numbers," Lynch says. Big revenue losses mean that the U.S. budget deficit may be larger than predicted this year and in future years. Source: "http://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/taxes/2009-05-26-irs-tax-revenue-down_N.htm"
reply: So, someone explain to me again exactly how Obama is going to cut the deficit in half, and pay for his liberal spending bonanza for all of his social programs? How high will he have to raise taxes on those who still have jobs? We already have too many dollars chasing too few goods, which is going to result in massive inflation, and less spending, which means even less tax revenue for the Federal coffers.  "The World's Finest"

content: quote: Originally posted by ELLIOTT1980: O K . . ., BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! Now that I have the LIBs attention . . ., how does two wrongs, PO growing the Federal Government ever larger than BUSH 43..., gonna fix the problem . . . I'm getting this 'Deja Vu' of two wrongs, dang sure, don't make a right . . ., please explain It is not a matter of two wrongs making a right – it is a matter of what’s the difference? Republicans who call the kettle black when it got burned up on their watch have no credibility – that is why referring to what happened when Republicans controlled Congress and the White House matters. Under President Bush’s supervision, the national dept grew from $5.706 trillion in 2000 to $8.507 trillion in October 2007. That is DURING THE TIME THAT THE REPUBLICANS CONTROLLED CONGRESS – without one veto from President Bush. Note for those who will make excuses for President Bush: the GWOT represented only half a trillion dollars of the almost three trillion dollars that was overspent from January 2000 until October 2007, when the last Republican budget ended. From an article published in June 2004 – it got worse after this revelation, before the Republicans lost control of Congress: "Since 2001, even with record low inflation, U.S. federal spending has increased by a massive 28.8% (19.7% in real dollars)—with non-defense discretionary growth of 35.7% (25.3% in real dollars)—the highest rate of federal government growth since the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Lyndon Johnson.. President George W. Bush is now on his way to becoming the first full-term president since John Quincy Adams (1825-1829) to not veto a single bill. The result is a congress that has been completely unconstrained in satiating its appetite for pork and corporate welfare. From the massive increases in agricultural subsidies in the farm bill of 2002, to the new Medicare prescription drug entitlement of 2003, to the 80% increase in education spending, George W. Bush has demonstrated that “limited government” is not part of his political vocabulary." >www.independent.org/newsroom/news_detail.asp?newsID=31]http://www.independent.org/new...detail.asp?newsID=31 I am against the spending by the Obama Administration also, but what is the alternative – the good old days of a Republican controlled government?
quote: Originally posted by ELLIOTT1980: O K . . ., BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! BUSH's FAULT ! ! ! Now that I have the LIBs attention . . ., how does two wrongs, PO growing the Federal Government ever larger than BUSH 43..., gonna fix the problem . . . I'm getting this 'Deja Vu' of two wrongs, dang sure, don't make a right . . ., please explain
reply: It is not a matter of two wrongs making a right – it is a matter of what’s the difference? Republicans who call the kettle black when it got burned up on their watch have no credibility – that is why referring to what happened when Republicans controlled Congress and the White House matters. Under President Bush’s supervision, the national dept grew from $5.706 trillion in 2000 to $8.507 trillion in October 2007. That is DURING THE TIME THAT THE REPUBLICANS CONTROLLED CONGRESS – without one veto from President Bush. Note for those who will make excuses for President Bush: the GWOT represented only half a trillion dollars of the almost three trillion dollars that was overspent from January 2000 until October 2007, when the last Republican budget ended. From an article published in June 2004 – it got worse after this revelation, before the Republicans lost control of Congress: "Since 2001, even with record low inflation, U.S. federal spending has increased by a massive 28.8% (19.7% in real dollars)—with non-defense discretionary growth of 35.7% (25.3% in real dollars)—the highest rate of federal government growth since the presidencies of Richard Nixon and Lyndon Johnson.. President George W. Bush is now on his way to becoming the first full-term president since John Quincy Adams (1825-1829) to not veto a single bill. The result is a congress that has been completely unconstrained in satiating its appetite for pork and corporate welfare. From the massive increases in agricultural subsidies in the farm bill of 2002, to the new Medicare prescription drug entitlement of 2003, to the 80% increase in education spending, George W. Bush has demonstrated that “limited government” is not part of his political vocabulary." >www.independent.org/newsroom/news_detail.asp?newsID=31]http://www.independent.org/new...detail.asp?newsID=31 I am against the spending by the Obama Administration also, but what is the alternative – the good old days of a Republican controlled government?

Where were questions like these when George W. Bush cut 1.6 trillion dollars in taxes and continued to increase government spending to record levels? They were there, by both conservatives and liberals alike, but the libs were the loudest. Now, though, it seems liberals have lost that outrage and turned into a cheering section... "The World's Finest"

reply: They were there, by both conservatives and liberals alike, but the libs were the loudest. Now, though, it seems liberals have lost that outrage and turned into a cheering section... "The World's Finest"

content: Listen up those of you who do not have a college education nor combat experience. When more than 3 million people in this country for what ever reason, lose their jobs, they can not and will not pay taxes. Thus the gov't and States must tax the ones that do have jobs to pay higher taxes. Now here is the real ash kicker. Once these 3 million get jobs and get their lives back in some type of order, the higher taxes never seem to shrink. So life continues and sooner or later those that work, want to work, just throw up their arms and say "Fork it. It just ain't worth it".

The underlying economic problems in the past few years was a bi-partisan effort, nobody having smarts or honesty enough to see what was coming or to honestly announce it. And its basis in time went back a number of administrations. Besides the economy diving, reduction of tax revenues also can be traced to people doing things with their money that are not ideal for economic growth, but which shield their money from Obama's taxes better. Taxes are going up on almost everybody, either directly or indirectly. Obama's misleading claims about taxes and the middle class during the campaign (has it stopped?) were based on incompetent ignorance or outright lying to gullible, inadequately educated citizens. Whatever you tax, you get less of. Tax income more, tax wealth more, get less income and wealth. Nation screwed.
